messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 60 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Proof.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Adversarial team games model multiplayer strategic interactions in which a team of identically-interested players is competing against an adversarial player in a zero-sum game. Such games capture many well-studied settings in game theory, such as congestion games, but go well-beyond to environments wherein the cooperation of one team‚Äîin the absence of explicit communication‚Äîis obstructed by competing entities; the latter setting remains poorly understood despite its numerous applications. Since the seminal work of Von Stengel and Koller (GEB ‚Äò97), different solution concepts have received attention from an algorithmic standpoint. Yet, the complexity of the standard Nash equilibrium has remained open. In this paper, we settle this question by showing that computing a Nash equilibrium in adversarial team games belongs to the class continuous local search (\ComplexityFont‚ÄãC‚ÄãL‚ÄãS\ComplexityFontùê∂ùêøùëÜ\ComplexityFont{CLS}), thereby establishing \ComplexityFont‚ÄãC‚ÄãL‚ÄãS\ComplexityFontùê∂ùêøùëÜ\ComplexityFont{CLS}-completeness by virtue of the recent \ComplexityFont‚ÄãC‚ÄãL‚ÄãS\ComplexityFontùê∂ùêøùëÜ\ComplexityFont{CLS}-hardness result of Rubinstein and Babichenko (STOC ‚Äò21) in potential games. To do so, we leverage linear programming duality to prove that any œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-approximate stationary strategy for the team can be extended in polynomial time to an O‚Äã(œµ)ùëÇitalic-œµO(\epsilon)-approximate Nash equilibrium, where the O‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëÇ‚ãÖO(\cdot) notation suppresses polynomial factors. As a consequence, we show that the Moreau envelop of a suitable best response function acts as a potential under certain natural gradient-based dynamics.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 60 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 60"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The equivalence of linear programs and zero-sum games",
        "Congestion games with malicious players",
        "Settling the complexity of nash equilibrium in congestion games",
        "Team-maxmin equilibrium: Efficiency bounds and algorithms",
        "Sampling equilibria: Fast no-regret learning in structured games",
        "The myth of the folk theorem",
        "A marriage between adversarial team games and 2-player games: Enabling abstractions, no-regret learning, and subgame solving",
        "Computational results for extensive-form adversarial team games",
        "Coordination in adversarial sequential team games via multi-agent deep reinforcement learning",
        "Settling the complexity of computing two-player nash equilibria",
        "On the np-completeness of finding an optimal strategy in games with common payoffs",
        "The nature of the firm",
        "On the complexity of approximating a nash equilibrium",
        "Continuous local search",
        "The game world is flat: The complexity of nash equilibria in succinct games",
        "The complexity of computing a nash equilibrium",
        "A converse to banach‚Äôs fixed point theorem and its cls-completeness",
        "Independent policy gradient methods for competitive reinforcement learning",
        "The complexity of constrained min-max optimization",
        "Stochastic subgradient method converges at the rate O(kùëòk-1/4-1/4{}^{\\mbox{-1/4}}) on weakly convex functions",
        "On the complexity of nash equilibria and other fixed points",
        "Ex ante coordination and collusion in zero-sum multi-player extensive-form games",
        "Connecting optimal ex-ante collusion in teams to extensive-form correlation: Faster algorithms and positive complexity results",
        "Cls: new problems and completeness",
        "Unique end of potential line",
        "The complexity of gradient descent: CLS = PPAD ‚à©\\cap PLS",
        "Arrival: next stop in cls",
        "Adventures in Monotone Complexity and TFNP",
        "Further collapses in TFNP",
        "Separations in proof complexity and TFNP",
        "Geometric algorithms and combinatorial optimization, volume 2",
        "Zero-sum games between mean-field teams: A common information and reachability based analysis",
        "Approximability and parameterized complexity of minmax values",
        "Distinguishability of sets of distributions",
        "Hardness of continuous local search: Query complexity and cryptographic lower bounds",
        "How easy is local search?",
        "Efficiently computing nash equilibria in adversarial team markov games",
        "Behavior strategies, mixed strategies and perfect recall",
        "Common information belief based dynamic programs for stochastic zero-sum games with competing teams",
        "Learning in zero-sum team markov games using factored value functions",
        "A faster cutting plane method and its implications for combinatorial and convex optimization",
        "On gradient descent ascent for nonconvex-concave minimax problems",
        "Elements for a theory of teams",
        "Non-cooperative games",
        "Near-neutrality in evolution of genes and gene regulation",
        "On the complexity of the parity argument and other inefficient proofs of existence",
        "Computing correlated equilibria in multi-player games",
        "On the interpretation of decision problems with imperfect recall",
        "A class of games possessing pure-strategy Nash equilibria",
        "Settling the complexity of computing approximate two-player nash equilibria",
        "The duality gap for two-team zero-sum games",
        "Path kernels and multiplicative updates",
        "The computational complexity of single-player imperfect-recall games",
        "Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (60th-Anniversary Edition)",
        "Team-maxmin equilibria",
        "Team correlated equilibria in zero-sum extensive-form games via tree decompositions",
        "Team belief DAG form: A concise representation for team-correlated game-theoretic decision making",
        "Converging to team-maxmin equilibria in zero-sum multiplayer games",
        "Computing team-maxmin equilibria in zero-sum multiplayer extensive-form games",
        "Computing ex ante coordinated team-maxmin equilibria in zero-sum multiplayer extensive-form games"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 60 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Proof., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
